newsitem.title: FINLAND: Amer promises competitive longer term ROI.
newsitem.headline: Amer promises competitive longer term ROI.

text.p: Loss-making Finnish sporting goods group Amer-Yhtyma Oy's CEO Roger Talermo promised in the annual report on Friday that a new focus would give shareholders competitive returns on investment in the longer term.
"For Amer's shareholders, the group's new focus ... will result in a better balanced risk together with competitive returns on their investment in the longer term," Talermo wrote in the report.
The turnaround would take time, he warned.
"Our ship cannot be turned around in a day, it will take two, three years," Talermo said.
"As the problems are broadly based, the measures introduced will need several years to take full effect," he said.

In the future, Amer would operate in branded sports and leisure products. In the group's sports division, Wilson (golf, tennis, team sports), Atomic (skis) and Oxygen (snowboards, in-line skates) were brands given "top priority", Talermo said.

"In accordance with the new strategy, both Wilson and Atomic's organisations are committed to premium products which are innovative, enhance game improvement and are targeted to the average consumer," he added.
Amer would offer wholesalers and retailers "a comprehensive sports portfolio from winter and summer sports, indoor to outdoor games, from traditional to trend sports," he said.
Amer's smaller units, Amer Tobacco and Time/system now had "clear strategies" for the short and medium term, Talermo said.
In 1996, Amer fell to a 234 million markka loss before extraordinary items and tax from a 140 million markka profit.
Return on investment was negative at 2.3 percent last year from a positive reading of 5.9 percent in 1995.
The annual report repeated that earnings would improve in 1997, but that overall, Amer "may remain lossmaking." --Helsinki newsroom +358-9-680 50 245, e-mail news@reuters.fi
